data.text: May We Stuff a Tent without Folding?

I need some more help people. Seems like I asked for more advice than I give. I have Parkinson's so I have limited mobility and strength in my hands. When it comes to packing a tent, is it okay to stuff it into a pannier or a dry bag without folding and rolling it? That is how I pack my sleeping bag I just stuff it into the bottom of my pannier. I have a 13 l ortlieb dry bag that I could stuff my tent, fly and ground sheet into very easily. My thinking is that when I got home I could always set it up to dry and fold it and Roll It and then store it and it's factory bag with some help from my wife. Any other easy Packing Tips would be appreciated
All good to stuff anything
data.author: Roberge Pat

data.text: Folding and rolling is actually discouraged as it can cause damage to the area at the fold. Stuff away!
data.author: Craig Turner

data.text: It's arguable that carefully folding and rolling a tent the same way every time risks creating permanent creases, and thus weakening the fabric. It's also arguable that randomly stuffing it into a bag would create different random creases each time - which might be less harmful ....
data.author: Peter James

data.text: Some believe that folding a tent is bad due to causing failure along the folds. I usually just stuff my tent in its bag--same with my sleeping bag.
data.author: Jeff McMichael

data.text: Yes, you can totally stuff your tent like a sleeping bag. I actually think it is better than consistently folding it the same way, which over time will cause wear on the folds.

data.text: It's better that you stuff your tent instead of folding and rolling. The reason for this is that folding and rolling continually stresses the materials in the same spots (folds) and causes it to break down and fail sooner. Many manufacturers prefer that you stuff instead of roll
